record.text: What are the benefits for representing a package as a DID? I would expect a DID to represent an identity who can publish a package, and so can own many. This is how lexicons on atproto work too

value.text: Thinking about this more, the only thing atproto really would need to support this is a way for DIDs/repos representing packages to be linked to DIDs/repos representing users who have the right to publish to them. Seems useful for social media also (shared accounts).

record.text: the way that a downstream service/index "bootstraps" the network hasn't changed: a combination of consuming relay firehose, and fetching older data as full CAR file exports.

So, can ATProto scale down? Have Bluesky's "scaling towards decentralization" issues been fixed?

Not fundamentally. There have been good advancements in self-hosting efforts, but my fundamental analysis of Bluesky and ATProto scaling quadratically have not changed. üßµ

What's being looked at is lightweight relays that are effectively relay *mirrors*.

But what's making them avoid the world-sized growing database is that they're dropping data older than 72 hours.
yes, weaker = decentralized; every cabinet this century has been increasingly the opposite

record.text: PPS should be at City Hall yelling about Inner Eastside for All, not Salem begging for money they're unlikely to get (I mean, do both, but don't do just Salem).

Setting aside the legitimate question on whether $1.83 billion is an appropriate price tag for three new PPS high schools, it remains obscene that this amount is *still* less than the current anticipated cost of the proposed $1.9 billion Rose Quarter Freeway www.wweek.com/news/schools...

i guess i'd respond it's fully prudent for PPS as an institution to be more cautious in planning for large neighborhood-specific student growth - PPS has no control over it! But the City of Portland has plenty of (housing) tools to deploy if we were ambitious about keeping families in town.
Also maybe it‚Äôs desirable in itself to add to their costs/prices. Uber undercut the market largely by not paying benefits to drivers.

For the past few years, there's been an assertion by many that AI pricing would only fall as models improved, but the reality is a spectrum of pricing crossing more than 3 orders of magnitude.

On one end is e.g. Gemimi 2.0 Flash-lite at $0.30 per M output tokens and on the other now o1-pro at $600!

So, can ATProto scale down? Have Bluesky's "scaling towards decentralization" issues been fixed?

Not fundamentally. There have been good advancements in self-hosting efforts, but my fundamental analysis of Bluesky and ATProto scaling quadratically have not changed. üßµ

I think the "quadratic" claim comes down to definition of features and administrative domains.

for the bluesky product, we think that access and interaction to the full public network is a core part of the experience; not just folks already in social graph

It's truly amazing that 1.5M+ Americans died in a 24 month period.... and it was no big deal.

This is the baseline of what's going to happen when mass wet bulb deaths start happening.

So, can ATProto scale down? Have Bluesky's "scaling towards decentralization" issues been fixed?

Not fundamentally. There have been good advancements in self-hosting efforts, but my fundamental analysis of Bluesky and ATProto scaling quadratically have not changed. üßµ

And none of this even remotely challenges my primary original argument: if there is no central source of authority and things are really decentralized, the network scales towards decentralization *quadratically*.
